items.message:
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Areas most at risk include low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge.
Weather conditions are expected to remain unsettled throughout Tuesday and Wednesday, with a heavier band of rain forecast on Thursday (although this has a lower confidence being 3 days away currently). Whilst the rivers have started to rise, they haven't risen as much as initially forecast yesterday. The flood alert level is now forecast to be met again this afternoon therefore the flood alert will remain in force.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: High river levels today, 13 January 2026, may lead to flooding. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Church Laneham to Rampton Road. There is further light rainfall forecast over the next 12 hours. River levels at Torksey Gauge are rising slowly and expected to remain high until 15/01/2026. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated after 17:00PM today, 13 January 2026, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of recent rainfall and snow melt. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.

River levels at Pillings Lock Gauge will remain high over the next few days. There is minimal further rainfall forecast today, 13/01/2026. We are closely monitoring the situation & checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 17:00PM on 13 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Flooding is expected. 

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected on the River Cherwell especially near Enslow, Thrupp and Kidlington. The high river levels are due to the heavy rainfall we saw on Thursday 8 January. The water has now made its way down the river. The weather forecast today (Tuesday 13 January) and tomorrow is mostly dry, with a few showers in places. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.

This message will be updated by 12:00PM, midday, on the 14 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected. Flood water is receding from the causeway at Sutton Gault. This information is correct as of 08:00 on 13 January 2026. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary. There are currently no issues on the Welney and Earith causeways. 
If you have been evacuated only return to your property once the emergency services have advised that it is safe to do so. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester
items.message:
Flood alert in force for the River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester 

Flooding is possible for: River Dee in England covers areas around Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington.

River levels remain high today and flooding is still possible on 13 January 2026. 

Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. Townfield Lane may potentially be cut off later today.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 14 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Flooding is possible on 12 January 2026 . 
Flooding may affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Bourne Brook. 
We are closely monitoring the situation .Further scattered showers are expected throughout today. 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 13 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high today. Flooding may continue on 13 January 2026. Flooding may affect low lying land & roads adjacent to the river from Highley to Tewkesbury; including Dog Lane Bewdley, Stourport, Diglis & Hylton Road towpath. Flooded drains affect the racecourse & Worcester CCG. PLP should be installed. New St Gate closed at Upton upon Severn. Predicted peaks:- Worcester 3.8m to 4.1m on 13/01 PM, Diglis 3.7m to 3.9m on 13/01 PM, Kempsey Yacht Club 5.9m to 6.1m on 13/01 PM, Saxons Lode 4.3m to 4.6m on 14/01 AM. Other gauge locations are not forecast to exceed Flood Alert thresholds. Further rainfall is forecast on Thursday 15/01. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 14 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high today. Flooding may continue on 13 January 2026. Flooding may affect low lying land and Squires Walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. Kempsey Flood Alleviation Scheme is currently operational from 12/01/2026. Predicted peak:- Kempsey Yacht Club 5.9m to 6.1m 13/01 PM. We are closely monitoring the situation. Further rainfall is forecast on Thursday 15/01. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses . This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 14 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels due to recent rainfall may lead to flooding of low-lying areas. The risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. Minimal rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. River levels at Willington and Shardlow Gauge are likely to remain high until 15/01/26. We are closely monitoring the situation. items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible in the West Dorset area. Groundwater levels are high in response to heavy rainfall earlier in December. Levels are slowly falling but remain high, and flooding of fields and roads is still possible. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 13th January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected. Minimal further rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

High river levels today may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 13 January.  Flooding is expected to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Trent between Kings Bromley to Clay Mills including Burton upon Trent. Further scattered showers are expected throughout today which will cause river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 14 January or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Hopwas river gauge as a result of rain and snow melt. Flooding is expected throughout today 12th January 2026 and overnight. Flooding may affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Tame between Hopwas and the National Arboretum at Alrewas. Further scattered showers are expected throughout today which will cause river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 13th January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 13 January 2026 from early afternoon. 
River levels remain high and further rainfall is forecast for today so flooding is possible. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers, particularly in the Abridge area. 
Property flooding is not expected. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking river and rainfall levels. 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 13 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message:
Rising river levels today may lead to flooding.

Flooding is possible on 13 January 2026.

Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near the River Foulness and the Market Weighton Canal and their tributaries, particularly around Welham Bridge.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 9PM on 13 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Further rainfall is forecast but no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the South Winterbourne Valley
items.message: High groundwater levels are still expected to cause flooding. Flooding is still expected from 6th January 2026 onwards. Groundwater levels in West Dorset remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Winterbourne Abbas, Winterbourne Steepleton, Martinstown, Winterbourne Monkton, Winterbourne Herringston and Winterbourne Came. The groundwater level at the Kingston Russell borehole has fallen to 116.68m, and is expected to fall further over the next few days. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected. Roads may be damaged by floodwater. Any intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation. If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts. This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 13th January 2026, or as the situation changes.
